metadata.title: Discrete Structures
metadata.prerequisite: CSC221 (Programming and Algorithms I) AND MTH80 (Intermediate Algebra for STEM)

description.catalog: This course covers the mathematical foundations of computer science including logic, proof techniques, sets, relations, functions, counting, discrete probability, graphs, and trees. Students will develop skills in mathematical reasoning, proof writing, and algorithm analysis while implementing key concepts in a programming language.
description.expanded: Topics include symbolic logic and proof methods, combinatorics, set theory, graph and tree traversal methods, mathematical induction, recursion, and recurrence relations. Students apply discrete mathematics concepts through programming exercises in Java or C++, developing both theoretical understanding and practical implementation skills. This course provides essential foundations for advanced study in algorithms, data structures, software engineering, and theoretical computer science.

purpose.why: Discrete mathematics is the mathematical foundation of computer science, essential for understanding algorithms, data structures, complexity analysis, and software correctness. This course develops the rigorous mathematical reasoning skills needed for advanced CS coursework and professional software development. The combination of theory and programming implementation prepares you for technical interviews, algorithm design, and system analysis.
purpose.beyond: Beyond programming skills, you'll develop logical thinking, proof construction, and problem-solving abilities applicable across all STEM fields. You'll learn to analyze computational complexity, prove algorithm correctness, and make data-driven decisions—skills valued in software engineering, data science, cybersecurity, and research roles.

slos: Apply symbolic logic and proof methods to model and analyze program/algorithm correctness
Apply combinatorics and set theory to counting problems
Implement graph/tree traversal methods in a programming language
Explain the relationship between mathematical induction and recursion/recurrence equations, and their relationship to computing systems

phases.title: Phase 1: Sets, Relations, and Logic Foundations (Weeks 1-3)
phases.description: Introduction to set theory, relations, functions, and propositional logic

weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Unit 1: Sets, Set Relations, and Set Functions (Sections 1.1-1.2)
assignments: Programming Exercise 1: Set Operations Implementation (15 pts)
Problem Set 1: Set Theory and Operations (10 pts)
Discussion Post 1: Why Discrete Structures Matters in CS (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Course setup week - establish foundational concepts

weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Unit 1: Sets, Set Relations, and Set Functions (Sections 1.3-1.5)
assignments: Programming Exercise 2: Relations Property Checker (15 pts)
Problem Set 2: Relations and Functions (10 pts)
Discussion Post 2: Real-world Applications of Relations and Functions (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Relations are fundamental for database theory

topics: Logical connectives (AND, OR, NOT, implication, biconditional)
weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Unit 1 (Cardinality); Unit 3: Mathematical Logic (Sections 3.1-3.2)
assignments: Programming Exercise 3: Truth Table Generator (15 pts)
Discussion Post 3: Logic in Programming - Boolean Expressions (3 pts)
Quiz 1: Sets, Relations, Functions, Basic Logic (30 pts)

phases.title: Phase 2: Advanced Logic and Proof Techniques (Weeks 4-6)
phases.description: Predicate logic, proof methods, and mathematical induction

assignments: Programming Exercise 4: Logic Expression Simplifier (15 pts)
Problem Set 3: Predicate Logic and Quantifiers (10 pts)
Discussion Post 4: Quantifiers in Database Queries (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Predicate logic essential for program specification

weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Unit 4: Mathematical Induction and Proofs (Sections 4.1-4.2)
assignments: Problem Set 4: Direct Proofs and Contrapositive (15 pts)
Discussion Post 5: Famous Mathematical Proofs Discussion (3 pts)
Programming Project 1 ASSIGNED: Logic and Proof Systems (80 pts)
weeks.notes: Major Project 1 assigned this week - due end of Week 6

weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Unit 4: Mathematical Induction and Proofs (Sections 4.3-4.5)
assignments: Programming Exercise 5: Induction Proof Portfolio (10 pts)
Discussion Post 6: Mathematical Induction vs. Recursion (4 pts)
Programming Project 1 DUE: Logic and Proof Systems (80 pts)
Quiz 2: Proof Techniques and Counting Basics (30 pts)
weeks.notes: Major Project 1 due; Second quiz - covers Weeks 4-6

topics: Basic counting principles (sum and product rules)
assignments: Programming Exercise 6: Counting Problems Implementation (10 pts)
Problem Set 5: Counting Principles and Applications (15 pts)
Discussion Post 7: Counting Problems in Everyday Life (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Counting principles essential for algorithm analysis

assignments: Programming Exercise 7: Binomial Coefficient Calculator (10 pts)
Discussion Post 8: The Birthday Paradox and Probability (4 pts)
weeks.notes: Advanced counting techniques for complex problems

assignments: Problem Set 6: Probability and Bayes' Theorem (15 pts)
Discussion Post 9: Probability in Algorithm Analysis (3 pts)
Quiz 3: Discrete Probability and Recursion (30 pts)
Midterm Exam: Weeks 1-8 (150 pts)
weeks.notes: Quiz 3 and Midterm Exam - major assessment week

assignments: No assignments due during Spring Break
weeks.notes: Use this time to review and catch up if needed

phases.title: Phase 4: Recursion and Recurrence Relations (Weeks 10-11)
phases.description: Recursive algorithms and solving recurrence relations

assignments: Problem Set 7: Recursion and Mathematical Induction (15 pts)
Discussion Post 10: Recursive Thinking in Problem Solving (4 pts)
Programming Project 2 ASSIGNED: Combinatorics and Probability Toolkit (85 pts)
weeks.notes: Major Project 2 assigned this week - due end of Week 11

assignments: Programming Exercise 8: Recurrence Relation Solver (15 pts)
Discussion Post 11: Analyzing Algorithm Complexity (3 pts)
Programming Project 2 DUE: Combinatorics and Probability Toolkit (85 pts)

phases.title: Phase 5: Graph Theory and Algorithms (Weeks 12-14)
phases.description: Graph representations, traversals, and fundamental graph algorithms

assignments: Programming Exercise 9: Graph Data Structure Library (20 pts)
Discussion Post 12: Graph Theory in Social Networks (3 pts)
Programming Exercise 10: BFS and DFS Implementation (20 pts)
Problem Set 8: Graph Theory Problems (10 pts)
Discussion Post 13: Traversal Algorithms - When to Use Which? (3 pts)
Quiz 4: Graphs and Basic Trees (30 pts)
Programming Exercise 11: MST and Shortest Path Algorithms (20 pts)
Discussion Post 14: Real-world MST Applications (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Classic graph algorithms with practical applications

phases.title: Phase 6: Tree Structures and Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-16)
phases.description: Binary trees, tree traversals, AVL trees, and hash tables

topics: Binary trees and binary search trees
weeks.readings: Saylor.org CS202 Supplementary tree materials; Review graph theory tree sections
assignments: Programming Exercise 12: Tree Traversal Implementations (15 pts)
Discussion Post 15: Tree Structures in File Systems (3 pts)
Programming Project 3 ASSIGNED: Tree Data Structures Library (85 pts)
weeks.notes: Major Project 3 assigned this week - due end of Week 16

assignments: Programming Exercise 13: AVL Tree Implementation (15 pts)
Programming Exercise 14: Hash Table with Collision Resolution (15 pts)
Programming Project 3 DUE: Tree Data Structures Library (85 pts)
Quiz 5: Advanced Trees and Hashing (30 pts)
weeks.notes: Major Project 3 due; Fifth quiz - covers Weeks 14-16

assignments: Final Exam: Comprehensive (150 pts)

components.description: Hands-on programming assignments implementing discrete structures concepts in Java or C++
Written mathematical proofs, analysis, and theoretical problem-solving
Weekly online discussion forums on concepts and applications

components.details: 3 major projects = 250 points (Project 1: 80 pts, Project 2: 85 pts, Project 3: 85 pts)
components.description: Independent programming projects synthesizing multiple weeks of content
Knowledge checks at key milestones covering 2-4 weeks of material each
Comprehensive exam covering Weeks 1-8 (before Spring Break)
Comprehensive final examination covering all course content

grading.bonusOpportunities: Up to 30 extra credit points available through optional assignments: Algorithm Visualization Video (10 pts), Research Paper Summary (10 pts), LeetCode Graph/Tree Challenge (10 pts). Extra credit cannot replace major assignments but can boost final grade by up to 3%.
grading.passingGrade: C (70%) required for CS majors and prerequisite for CSC222 and other advanced courses

policies.attendance: Attendance is not directly graded but strongly encouraged. Discussion participation (5% of grade) requires weekly engagement. Missing class may significantly impact understanding and performance.
policies.lateWork: Programming Exercises & Problem Sets: 10% deduction per day, accepted up to 3 days late. Programming Projects: 15% first 24 hours, 25% second 24 hours, 40% third 24 hours, then 0%. Quizzes: No makeup without documented emergency. Discussions: 50% penalty if late, maximum 2 days late.
policies.makeupWork: Quizzes and exams cannot be made up without documented emergency (medical, family emergency, etc.). Contact instructor within 24 hours for quizzes, 48 hours for exams. Labs and homework can be completed late with penalties as noted above.
policies.academicIntegrity: Acceptable: Discussing concepts and approaches with classmates, using course materials and recommended resources, asking clarifying questions, citing external resources properly. Not Acceptable: Copying code from others (students or internet), sharing solution code, using unauthorized resources during exams, submitting work done by someone else. Consequences: First offense: 0 on assignment + meeting with instructor. Second offense: F in course + referral to academic affairs. All incidents reported to department.
policies.collaboration: Encouraged: Discussing concepts, troubleshooting approaches, comparing strategies. Permitted: Helping classmates understand errors or techniques. Prohibited: Copying code, sharing quiz answers, submitting identical work.
policies.aiUsage: Generative AI can be used in specific assignments in this course. Students will receive guidelines for using AI responsibly, with clear expectations on what is permitted and how to cite your usage. The use of AI tools beyond the guidelines of each assignment is considered plagiarism in this course, and disciplinary actions fall under the plagiarism guidelines.

successTips: Start assignments early - proofs and programming both take longer than you expect
Practice regularly, not just before exams - discrete math requires consistent engagement
Work through textbook examples thoroughly before attempting homework
Attend office hours when stuck - mathematical concepts build on each other
Form study groups to discuss proofs and approaches
Keep detailed notes with worked examples for exam preparation
Test your programs thoroughly with edge cases and various inputs
Review fundamental algebra and logic concepts if needed
Use visualization tools (Visualgo, GeoGebra) to understand graphs and trees
Connect concepts to programming - discrete math is the foundation of CS theory
Prepare note sheets thoughtfully for exams - the process of creating them helps learning
Don't wait until project deadlines - start projects as soon as they're assigned
Practice LeetCode/HackerRank graph and tree problems for additional challenges
Explain concepts to classmates - teaching reinforces your own understanding
Plan for 9-10 hours per week on average, 12-15 hours during project weeks

alignedCertifications.name: C-ID COMP-152
alignedCertifications.description: State-wide curriculum standard for discrete structures courses
alignedCertifications.courseAlignment: Course fully aligned with C-ID COMP-152 requirements: Functions, Relations and Sets; Basic Logic; Proof Techniques; Basics of Counting; Graphs and Trees; Discrete Probability

supplementary.title: Book of Proof
supplementary.author: Richard Hammack
supplementary.notes: Excellent free resource for proof writing

supplementary.title: Mathematics for Computer Science
supplementary.author: Eric Lehman, F. Thomson Leighton, Albert R. Meyer

project1.name: Logic and Proof Systems
project1.topics: Propositional logic, truth tables, logical equivalences, CNF/DNF, proof validation
components: Truth Table Generator (20 pts) - Parse expressions, generate tables, identify tautologies
Logical Equivalence Checker (20 pts) - Compare expressions, show counterexamples
Normal Form Converter (20 pts) - Convert to CNF/DNF, simplify expressions
Proof Step Validator (20 pts) - Validate inferences, detect fallacies
project1.deliverables: Source code (Java/C++), README, test cases, design document (1-2 pages)
project1.rubric: Functionality 50%, Code Quality 20%, Documentation 15%, Testing 10%, Design Document 5%

project2.name: Combinatorics and Probability Toolkit
project2.topics: Set operations, counting, permutations, combinations, probability, distributions
components: Set Operations Module (15 pts) - Union, intersection, Cartesian product, power sets
Counting Module (20 pts) - Permutations, combinations, Pascal's triangle, factorials
Probability Calculator (25 pts) - Sample spaces, conditional probability, Bayes' theorem
Distribution Problems Solver (15 pts) - Stars and bars, constrained distributions
Binomial Theorem (10 pts) - Expand (a+b)^n, calculate specific terms
project2.deliverables: Source code, user interface (console/GUI), README, test suite, user guide (2-3 pages)
project2.rubric: Functionality 50%, Integration 10%, Code Quality 15%, UI 10%, Documentation 10%, Testing 5%

project3.name: Tree Data Structures Library
project3.topics: Binary trees, BST, tree traversals, AVL trees, expression trees
components: Binary Tree Implementation (15 pts) - Node structure, basic operations
Binary Search Tree (25 pts) - Insert, delete, search, maintain BST property
Tree Traversals (20 pts) - Inorder, preorder, postorder, level-order (recursive and iterative)
AVL Tree (15 pts) - Rotations, balance maintenance (optional bonus)
Expression Tree (10 pts) - Parse and evaluate arithmetic expressions
project3.deliverables: Source code with complete library, comprehensive test suite, API documentation, performance analysis report
project3.rubric: Functionality 50%, Correctness 20%, Code Quality 15%, Testing 10%, Documentation 5%

weeklyWorkloadEstimate.projectWeeks: 12-15 hours (includes 5-6 hours additional for major project work)
weeklyWorkloadEstimate.examWeeks: Additional 3-5 hours for exam preparation and review
